metadata./Title: Exponential decline, ceiling effect, downregulation, and T-cell response in immunoglobulin G antibody levels after messenger RNA vaccine boosters: a case report

sections.Background:
Background Vaccine protection against severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 infection reduces gradually over time, requiring administration of updated boosters. However, long-term immune response following up to 
the sixth dose of the messenger RNA vaccine has not been well studied.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation We longitudinally determined anti-spike protein immunoglobulin G antibody levels in a 69-year-old 
Japanese man 76 times (first to sixth dose) to investigate their dynamics. Regarding the messenger RNA BNT162b2 vaccine, 
first to fourth doses were identical monovalent vaccines, and fifth and sixth doses were identical bivalent vaccines. T-cell 
responses after fourth and fifth doses were studied using T-SPOT. Immunoglobulin G levels peaked at 1–2 weeks after second to sixth dose, declining exponentially after each dose. The decline was approximated using the formula f (t) = A e−t/τ + C. 
Time constant τ  increased with each booster vaccination, indicating a decreasing rate of antibody titer decay with increasing number of doses. Baseline and peak immunoglobulin G levels were similar in the second and third dose. Conversely, 
baseline immunoglobulin G levels after the fourth dose increased over fivefold over the second and third dose; however, 
peak immunoglobulin G levels after fourth dose decreased to 60% of those after the third dose. Baseline immunoglobulin G 
levels after the sixth dose increased 1.4-fold over the fifth dose; however, peak immunoglobulin G levels after the sixth dose 
decreased to 56% of those after the fifth dose. Dynamics of T-cell responses differed from those of immunoglobulin G antibodies. T cell responses increased gradually; however, their peak level was difficult to determine.
Conclusions Ceiling effect or downregulation of peak immunoglobulin G levels was clearly observed after messenger RNA booster vaccination. After peaking, the IgG level declined exponentially, and the rate of decay decreased 
with each subsequent booster. Although this was a single-case study, this data may provide a generalized mathematical decay model for humoral immunity in healthy older adults. Moreover, our study provides insights into the immunogenicity after booster vaccination with messenger RNA vaccines.
Keywords  BNT162b2, Antibody, T-SPOT, Ceiling effectOpen Access

Background
As of March 2024, severe acute respiratory syndrome 
coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection, responsible for 
the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, 
has affected over 800 million people globally, leading 
to 8 million deaths [1]. Efficacy of the messenger RNA 
(mRNA) vaccine BNT162b2 (Pfizer–BioNTech) was ini tially demonstrated in a randomized comparative study 
[2], leading to global vaccination campaigns. Moreover, 
vaccines and booster doses have been developed rapidly 
in response to the pandemic, reducing transmissibility, 
disease severity, and overall mortality [3]. Vaccine pro tection against SARS-CoV-2 infection reduces gradually 
over time, requiring administration of updated boosters. 
In most cases, SARS-CoV-2 infection
sections.Results:
results in self-lim iting symptoms; however, patients with risk factors, such 
as underlying heart or lung disease, diabetes, immuno suppression, and the older population, may require hos pitalization and develop a severe form of the disease [4]. 
Immunosenescence in the older population reduces the 
immunogenicity and efficacy of the vaccine as S proteinspecific immunoglobulin G (IgG) titers are significantly 
reduced, and S protein-specific CD4 and CD8 T-cell 
immunity was limited in individuals initially vaccinated 
with BNT162b2 [5]. Immunosenescence is not com pletely understood and development of booster vaccina tion strategies for the older population is crucial in the 
post-Omicron era.
Among the SARS-CoV-2 structural proteins, spike and 
nucleocapsid proteins are the major immunogens. Evalu ation of antibodies against the spike receptor-binding 
domain (RBD) IgG is important for accessing the protec tion against SARS-CoV-2 infection because of its neu tralizing activity [6]. Antibodies produced due to the 
mRNA vaccine specifically target RBD in the S1 subu nit of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein [7]. In the immune 
response induced by the mRNA vaccine, quantity, func tion, and lifespan of immunological memory cells is vital 
[8]. IgG antibody levels against the SARS-CoV-2 S pro tein (RBD) are being investigated to evaluate humoral 
immune response after vaccinations. Various models, 
including linear regression one-phase decay model [8], 
Bayesian linear mixed models [9], and exponential model 
[10], have been proposed to describe the decay pattern 
of IgG antibodies. However, a mathematical model ana lyzing long-term dynamics up to the sixth dose is yet to 
be established. Studies have reported a plateau or ceil ing effect in terms of antibody response after booster 
dose [11, 12]. Thus, further investigation on the antibody 
response dynamics after booster vaccination may provide 
insights into future vaccination strategies [6, 11].
In this study, we conducted a detailed longitudinal 
analysis of IgG antibody dynamics from before the first dose of the BNT162b2 vaccine to 5 months after the sixth 
dose, spanning a period of 2.5 years, in older men. After 
the fourth and fifth doses, levels of IgG antibodies as a 
humoral immune response were compared with T-cell 
responses as a cellular immune response (T-SPOT® 
COVID, Oxford Immunotec Ltd.). This study is simple 
yet unique, and to the best of our knowledge, no similar 
reports are found in the literature.
Case presentation
Participant and procedure
The study participant was a 69-year-old Japanese man 
with no underlying diseases except for hypertension, no 
history of smoking, and a body mass index of 21. Initial 
dose of the BNT162b2 vaccine was administered on 23 
April 2021, second dose on 14 May 2021 (21  days after 
the first dose), third dose on 25 December 2021 (216 days 
after the second dose), fourth dose on 29 July 2022 
(227 days after the third dose), fifth dose on 24 Decem ber 2022 (147  days after the fourth dose), and sixth 
dose on 19 June 2023 (140 days after the fifth dose). All 
six were of the BNT162b2 vaccine. First to fourth doses 
were identical monovalent vaccines (wild-type [WT]), 
whereas the fifth and sixth doses were identical bivalent 
(Omicron BA.4 and BA5 containing) vaccines. All doses 
were 0.3 cc each. Throughout the observation course, the 
participant did not contract COVID-19, which was con firmed by three negative anti-nucleocapsid antibody tests 
and monitoring of IgG antibody dynamics.
Measurement of anti‑spike protein IgG antibody levels
Architect SARS-CoV-2 IgG II Quant assay (Abbott, 
USA) was used for evaluating the antibody levels [13, 14], 
quantitatively measuring serum anti-spike protein IgG 
antibody levels. Blood samples were collected periodi cally according to the study design. Antibody measure ments were performed by a commercial laboratory (BML 
Inc., Japan). The cutoff level for this assay was 50 AU/mL.
Measurement interval
IgG antibody levels were measured at regular intervals, 
starting on the day of confirmation of negative results 
prior to the first BNT162b2 dose, 2 weeks after the first 
dose, at the time of the second dose, and with 1  week 
intervals until 1  month after the second dose. Subse quently, measurements were taken at the time of the 
third dose, weekly until 1 month after the third dose, and 
approximately every 2 weeks thereafter. After the fourth 
dose, measurements were taken twice a week for the 
first month and approximately every 2 weeks thereafter. 
Measurement intervals after the fifth and sixth dose were 
weekly for the first month and every 2–4  weeks there after. Overall, 76 tests were performed, with a 13-day

[IQR]: 7–14 days) (Supplementary Table 1).
Mathematical model of decay characteristics
Fluctuations in IgG antibody levels after vaccination were 
measured using an approximate equation of the form f 
(t) = Ae−t/τ + C, where τ is the time constant; the charac teristics of each antibody response were examined. We 
also determined the time required for the peak antibody 
level to decrease by half (tmax/2 ) using an exponential 
function.
T‑cell response
We investigated T-cell response up to 8  months after 
the fourth dose using the T-SPOT®. COVID kit (Oxford 
Immunotec, UK) [15]; samples were outsourced to a 
commercial laboratory (LSI Medience Corporation, 
Japan). T-cell response was analyzed simultaneously with 
IgG antibody levels on the same day. The test was per formed at intervals of twice a week for the first month 
after the fourth and fifth dose, once a week for the follow ing month, and every 2 weeks thereafter. Overall, 24 tests 
were performed, with a median test interval of 7  days 
(IQR: 4–14 days).
T‑SPOT® COVID
Based on standardized enzyme-linked immunospot 
(ELISPOT) technology, T-SPOT® COVID test detects 
T cells reactive to SARS-CoV-2 [16]. After vaccination, 
naïve T cells differentiate into SARS-CoV-2-specific T 
cells (CD4/CD8). Peripheral blood mononuclear cells 
(PBMCs) containing these specific T cells were used as 
a sample. After blood collection, PBMCs were isolated from the blood and washed, and cell count was deter mined and adjusted to a constant number. PBMCs were 
then cultured with virus peptides derived from SARSCoV-2 using an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay 
plate and stimulated T-cell released cytokines (IFNγ). Cells were then removed from the plate and alka line phosphatase-labeled antibodies and substrate were 
added. Labeled antibodies had bound to IFN-γ, and spots 
were visualized. Each spot represented one T cell, and the 
number of spot-forming cells (SFCs) responding to the 
specific antigen was counted; cutoff level was eight spots. 
Measurements were performed using an automatic ELIS POT plate reader and manually verified.
IgG antibody dynamics
Dynamics of the anti-spike (RBD) IgG antibody level 
from 2  weeks after the first dose of the vaccine to 
5  months after the sixth dose are illustrated in Fig.  1. 
Antibody levels were slightly positive at 71 AU/mL 
2  weeks after the first dose. Although the antibody 
levels at the time of the second and third doses were 
similar at 197 AU/mL and 184 AU/mL, respectively, 
the antibody level at the time of the fourth dose was 
1094 AU/mL, which was five times higher than that 
of the second or third dose. Antibody levels peaked 
7 days after the second and fifth doses and 14 days after 
the third, fourth, and sixth doses. Peak antibody lev els increased slightly to 7831 AU/mL after the second 
dose and to 8897 AU/mL after the third dose. Antibody 
level after the fourth dose decreased to 5469 AU/mL, 
60% lower than the level after the third dose. The fifth 
and sixth doses were bivalent vaccines. Compared with 
the peak antibody level of 11,000 AU/mL after the fifth

sections.Discussion:
Discussion and conclusions
Exponential decline of IgG antibody levels 
and establishment of a mathematical model
In studies regarding humoral immunity based on IgG 
antibody levels, timing of antibody level measurement 
after vaccination is crucial. Initial antibody titer after vac cination depends on the period from vaccination to test ing and reaches a peak 1–2 weeks after the booster dose 
[17]. One month after vaccination, IgG antibody levels 
decreased to 43% of the level at 1  week and decreased 
further after 3 months to 11% of the level at 1 week [13]. 
Compared with IgG antibody studies after monova lent vaccines, there are only a few for bivalent vaccines. 
Recent reports indicate that the IgG antibody levels after 
the second booster dose in the WT and WT + Omicron 
BA.1 group were similar [18]. IgG titer decay model 
after mRNA vaccination has not been fully established. 
In this case, IgG antibody levels after second to sixth 
dose peaked after 1–2 weeks followed by an exponential 
decline. Although several mathematical models regard ing IgG antibody decay have been presented [8–10], 
they were based on the IgG antibody levels measured 
3–4 times after vaccination. Thus, it has been difficult 
to establish a mathematical model for the long-term 
dynamics of IgG antibodies. This example may be the first report to prove exponential decay, and data obtained 
in this study may serve as a mathematical model.
Baseline antibody levels, ceiling effect, 
and downregulation
Few studies have evaluated peak IgG antibody levels 
after the fourth dose [19]. In the present case, baseline 
and peak antibody levels were similar between second 
and third vaccinations, suggesting that the booster effect 
of the third vaccination on peak antibody levels was 
suppressed.
Some studies have shown that the fourth dose does not 
enhance humoral and cell-mediated immunity compared 
with the third dose, especially in cases with high baseline 
antibody levels, suggesting a ceiling effect [11, 20]. Inter estingly, our study revealed that baseline antibody levels 
at the fourth dose increased fivefold over the third dose, 
and peak antibody levels after the fourth dose decreased 
to 60% of those after the third dose. Downregulation may 
have occurred after the fourth dose. Moreover, our study 
also suggests that similar downregulation was observed 
after the sixth vaccination with a bivalent vaccine booster 
dose. Consistent with our findings, recent reports reveal 
slower decay kinetics after booster doses with a ceiling 
effect on the overall peak antibody titer obtained after 
each booster dose [21].
Recently, it has been suggested that restricted reacti vation of memory B cells (MBCs) suppresses antibody

levels after a booster dose [20]. Biochemical and molec ular biological mechanisms by which antibody levels 
are attenuated after mRNA vaccination boosting are 
not yet completely understood.
Extrafollicular (EF) response suppression
IgG antibody levels peak 1–2 weeks after booster dose [17], 
primarily due to the activation of MBCs and short-lived 
plasma cells (SLPCs) in EF responses. MBCs generated in 
EF responses are heterogeneously distributed and induce 
long-term immunity. These MBCs rapidly differentiate into 
plasma blasts and antibody-secreting cells (ASCs), leading 
to an initial burst through potent and diverse low-affinity 
secondary responses [22, 23]. Apoptosis of peripheral B 
cells and SLPCs occurs during the early phase, resulting in 
decreased antibody levels. The MBCs generated in the EF 
response form a distinct cluster from the MBCs responsi ble for cell-to-cell interactions in the germinal center (GC) 
response [24]. Excessive EF responses following SARSCoV-2 infection release a large amount of antibodies and 
inflammatory cytokines that correlate with disease severity 
[25]. In severe cases, cytokine storm overexpression of tumor 
necrosis factor-alpha inhibits GC formation and suppresses 
T follicular helper cell (Tfh) differentiation [26]. Suppress ing excessive antibody responses in SARS-CoV-2 infection is 
important, and recent studies suggest that mitochondria reg ulate EF B-cell responses during an infection [26]. Intracel lular calcium also regulates B-cell responses by suppressing 
mitochondrial function [27]. In this study, the peak antibody 
level was suppressed by booster vaccination, suggesting a 
mechanism of regulating early B-cell response in the EF.
Booster effect and follicular response
Following the EF response, B cells interact with anti gen in the GC response and are activated by antigenspecific  CD4+ Tfh. The activated B cells undergoing 
antigen-specific selection repeatedly proliferate and 
differentiate to produce high-affinity antibodies [22]. 
Some of the GC B cells enter a quiescent state as MBCs 
and are believed to survive for long durations in the 
bone marrow as terminally differentiated, long-lived 
plasma cells, producing majority of serum antibod ies [28]. A recent study revealed an increase in MBCs 
3  weeks after booster vaccination [29], which may be 
associated with a decreased rate of antibody decay with 
each booster vaccination in this study. It suggests that 
immune memory is enhanced after booster vaccination.SARS‑CoV‑2‑specific T‑cell response and immune 
senescence
Studies have reported on cell-mediated immunity fol lowing SARS-CoV-2 infection or vaccination. Moreo ver, numerous studies have investigated T cell responses 
using T-SPOT® COVID, but none have longitudinally 
assessed these responses through frequent testing, as 
in the present study. Increase in IgG antibodies after 
booster vaccination decline rapidly within 6  months, 
whereas MBCs and T-cell responses are still detect able 8 months after the second vaccination [30]. Reports 
on correlation between T cell responses and humoral 
immunity following vaccination vary, with some show ing weak correlation [31], moderate correlation [32], no 
correlation [33], or even inverse correlation [34], and the 
underlying mechanisms are not completely understood. 
Interestingly, in our case, IgG antibody levels peaked 
14  days after the fourth dose, whereas T-cell responses 
were weak and not proportional to antibody levels. T-cell 
responses after the fourth dose exhibited a mild peak, but 
after the fifth dose, it was difficult to detect. Weak T-cell 
response observed after the fourth and fifth doses in this 
case suggests the possibility of a ceiling effect in cellular 
immunity [35], individual differences [36], or immune 
senescence [36]. A study revealed that although B-cell 
intrinsic changes with age delay GC response in older 
adults, they do not impact differentiation into ASCs or 
their proliferation [37]. Spike-specific  CD4+ T cells, in 
older adults, suppress cell-mediated immune responses 
by expressing high levels of programmed cell death-1, 
which inhibits induction of spike-specific  CD8+ T cells 
[36]. Additionally, it has been suggested that the activity 
of regulatory T cells (Tregs) increases in the older popu lation and may be further enhanced by antigen stimula tion [38]. Furthermore, decline in vaccine efficacy with 
age is suggested to be due to increased Treg activity [39]. 
Recently, membrane-bound CD83 has been suggested as 
an important factor for Treg homeostasis and stability 
[40]. The SFC levels show large deviations compared to 
IgG antibody levels [41], and studies of T cell responses 
with T-SPOT® COVID should consider this devia tion. Thus, this study may represent the most common 
response of T cell immunity in the older population after 
booster vaccination.
COVID‑19 vaccines and the older population
In the post-Omicron era, SARS-CoV-2 reinfections 
have become common, with epidemics occurring dur ing summer and winter in Japan, and the older popula tion is substantially at risk of various cardiac, pulmonary, 
and neurological complications. A systematic review 
of COVID-19 vaccines analyzing data from nine and 21

 Hirano and Asada  Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:631 
 
studies found that their efficacy and immunogenicity 
were observed in people aged 55 years and older. Main 
determinants of the protective efficacy are choice of the 
primary vaccine (mRNA vaccines are more effective) and 
number of booster doses [42]. Similarly, a recent metaanalysis of 22 randomized controlled trials in adults 
aged 60 years and older revealed that COVID-19 vac cines were effective in preventing infection and reduc ing overall mortality in older adults, but they did not 
effectively reduce hospitalization rates or intensive care 
unit admission [43]. These studies indicate that the pri mary COVID-19 vaccine cycle is insufficient in providing 
protection against COVID-19 in the older population, 
and a booster shot strategy is required to strengthen 
and extend the immune response. This should be strate gized by considering factors that contribute to vaccine 
immunogenicity in the older population, such as dosage, 
interval between booster doses, addition of appropriate 
adjuvants to induce immune stimulation [44], and choice 
between homologous and heterologous vaccines.
Regarding vaccine dosage, increased IgG affin ity was observed after vaccination with a lower dose of 
the mRNA-1273 vaccine (50  µg versus standard dose 
of 100  µg) [45]. The study reported an inverse dose–
response relationship, with low doses of mRNA-1273 
sufficiently inducing noninferior immunity. Con versely, higher doses of Ad26.COV2.S induced humoral 
responses with a trend toward greater immunogenicity 
than lower doses, indicating a dose–response relation ship [46]. These studies were conducted during the early 
booster vaccination period, and there are few studies 
conducted during the period when the Omicron variant 
was rampant; therefore, further research is needed.
In booster vaccinations with mRNA vaccines at 6-, 
9-, and 12-month intervals, cumulative frequency of 
COVID-19 infection and risk of hospitalization or death 
were substantially reduced by booster vaccinations at 
shorter intervals. Booster vaccinations were more effec tive in people aged ≥ 65 years than in those aged < 65 
years [47]. Similar studies on booster intervals showed 
that 84 days were more effective than 56 days [46], and 84 
days were more effective than 28 days [45]. These stud ies suggest that an interval of approximately 3–6 months 
between early booster vaccinations is effective; however, 
as no similar studies have been conducted in the Omi cron era, vaccination interval to optimize immunogenic ity has yet to be determined. In Japan, vaccinations were 
administered nearly twice annually until 2023, but they 
will be administered once a year from 2024.
Use of heterologous prime-boost COVID-19 
vaccine schedules may facilitate mass vaccina tion against COVID-19. However, the heterologous 
BNT162b2 + mRNA-1273 vaccination schedule led to a noninferior immune response compared with the refer ence schedule [45]. Regarding the immunogenicity of 
heterologous schedules with an adenovirus vector vac cine and an mRNA vaccine, it has been confirmed that 
heterologous and homologous schedules of ChAdOx1 
nCoV-19 and BNT162b2 can induce comparable immune 
responses with a 4-week prime-boost interval [48].
During the 5 years of the COVID-19 pandemic, a large 
number of people were infected naturally. In an observa tional study on the impact of prior SARS-CoV-2 infection 
on immunity following booster vaccination with a biva lent BA.4/5-adapted mRNA vaccine, previously infected 
individuals had higher vaccine-induced anti-spike IgG 
antibodies and neutralizing titers; however, the relative 
increase was significantly higher in noninfected individu als [49]. This suggests that booster vaccination strategies 
in the older population should consider the prior infec tion status.
In our study, IgG levels peaked at 1–2 weeks after the 
second to sixth doses, and subsequently declined expo nentially with each dose, which was approximated using 
the following equation: f(t) = Ae − t/τ + C. If a threshold 
that can prevent COVID-19 is identified, optimal booster 
interval for the older population may be mathematically 
applicable.
Limitations of this study include its single-participant 
nature and absence of investigation on MBCs. Addition ally, data on T-cell responses were only available after the 
fourth and fifth doses. The effectiveness of booster vac cinations depends on the choice of vaccine type, optimal 
vaccine dosage, timing of vaccination, and decay kinetics 
of antibody response. Thus, further studies are needed to 
explore the early humoral immune response, alteration 
of immune memory by each booster vaccination, and 
mechanisms of interaction between humoral and cellular 
immune responses.
In
sections.Conclusion:
conclusion, we report detailed long-term immune 
responses up to the sixth dose of the mRNA vaccine in 
an older patient. Ceiling effect or downregulation of peak 
IgG levels was clearly observed after mRNA booster vac cination. Following the peak IgG levels, an exponential 
decrease was observed with each booster. Furthermore, 
the rate of decay decreased after monovalent and biva lent booster vaccines, indicating that immune memory 
was maintained and strengthened.
Dynamics of the T-cell response differed from those of 
IgG antibodies, which were less reactive. Thus, our lon gitudinal IgG antibody case study provides insights into 
immunogenicity after booster doses and contributes to 
public health vaccination strategies for older adults in the 
post-Omicron era.
